ground_truth: He is silent for a moment, then blurts out. By this time, a small crowd has collected to watch the above scene. Violet is furious and talking in a loud voice, and George is trying to quiet her. As George stalks off, the crowd breaks into laughter. George is walking slowly past the Hatch home. He walks past the house a few yards, turns, and starts back again. Mary is looking out the window, watching George walk back and forth. But after a few steps, he turns around and starts back. George stops, startled, and looks up. George looks surprised at this. But Mary has disappeared from the window. Mary is running down the stairs. Mary looks in a mirror at the bottom of the stairs and fixes her hair. She is plainly excited at George's visit. She runs into the parlor and puts a sketch on an easel. It is a caricature of George throwing a lasso around the moon. Then she opens the front door and stands there waiting for George. George is struggling with the gate; he finally kicks it open and starts slowly up the path toward Mary. Mary and George are in the entrance hall. They go through the doorway into the parlor. George sees the cartoon on the easel and bends down for a close look at it. George and Mary are sitting on the divan. There is silence for a moment, then Mary joins in singing with the phonograph record which has been playing all through the above scene. He looks at his watch, as though about to leave. He is uncomfortable, and she tries desperately to keep the conversation alive. Mrs. Hatch, in a bathrobe and with her hair in curlers, is leaning over the banister as she calls: George and Mary are seated on the divan. George is aghast. As George leaves the room, the telephone in the hall starts ringing. Mary comes into the hall. As Mary picks up the phone, George comes in from the front porch. George has stopped, hat in hand, to hear the first greetings. She hands the instrument to George. Sam is seated at his desk, while a couple of his friends are nearby, with highballs in their hands. As she hears this, she hastily hangs up the extension phone on which she has been listening. Mary takes the telephone from George and holds it so that of necessity George's cheek is almost against hers. He is very conscious of her proximity. Mary is watching George interestedly. George is very conscious of her, close to him. As Mary listens, she turns to look at George, her lips almost on his lips. George can stand it no longer.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He pauses, then blurts out. A small crowd has gathered to watch. Violet is furious, speaking loudly, and George tries to calm her. As George leaves, the crowd laughs. Walking past the Hatch home, George turns back. Mary watches him from the window. Surprised, George stops, but Mary is no longer there. She's excited, runs downstairs, fixes her hair, and places a sketch of George lassoing the moon on an easel in the parlor. Opening the front door, she waits for George. George struggles with the gate, kicks it open, and approaches Mary. They enter the parlor, where George closely examines the sketch. Sitting on the divan, they share a silence before Mary sings with the phonograph. George checks his watch, uncomfortable; she tries to keep talking. Mrs. Hatch, in a bathrobe, calls from the banister. George is aghast. As he exits, the hall phone rings. Mary answers, and George listens with interest. She hands the phone to George. Sam sits at his desk, friends nearby with drinks. Hearing this, Mary hangs up the extension phone. She takes the telephone from George, bringing their cheeks close. George is aware of their proximity. Turning to look at George, Mary almost touches his lips, and George can't stand it any longer.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: He is silent, then suddenly speaks. A crowd gathers to watch. Violet is loudly furious, and George tries to calm her. As he leaves, the crowd laughs. George walks past the Hatch home, then returns. Mary watches from the window, excited. She runs, fixes her hair, and places a caricature of George on an easel. She waits at the door as George struggles with the gate but finally approaches. Inside the parlor, George examines the cartoon. They sit on the divan; after a silence, Mary starts singing with a record. He checks his watch, uncomfortable, while she tries to maintain conversation. Mrs. Hatch, in a bathrobe and curlers, calls from upstairs. As George leaves, the phone rings. Mary answers, and George listens from the porch. She hands him the phone. Sam is at his desk with friends. Mary hangs up her extension phone, takes the telephone from George, and holds it close. George is aware of their closeness. Mary watches him intently. As she listens, their lips almost touch, and George can bear it no longer.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He remains silent for a brief moment before suddenly blurting out unexpected words. By this time, a small crowd has gathered, intrigued and eager to witness this unfolding scene. Violet is absolutely furious, her voice rising to a loud volume, while George makes an attempt to calm her down. As George finally stalks off, the assembled crowd erupts into laughter. George is seen walking slowly past the familiar Hatch home. He continues to walk a few yards past the house before turning around and starting the journey back again. Mary, looking out from the window, is intently watching George as he paces back and forth. Yet, after only a few steps, he turns around once more and retraces his path. George suddenly stops, startled, and glances upward in surprise. But by that time, Mary has already vanished from the window. Mary is quickly running down the stairs, unable to contain her excitement about George's visit. At the bottom of the stairs, she pauses momentarily to look into a mirror and tidies her hair. She eagerly runs into the parlor and places a sketch on an easel. The sketch is a whimsical caricature depicting George throwing a lasso around the moon. Then, she opens the front door and stands there, waiting expectantly for George to arrive. George struggles with the gate; with some effort, he finally manages to kick it open and begins to walk slowly up the path toward Mary. Now, Mary and George find themselves together in the entrance hall. They proceed through the doorway and enter the parlor. There, George notices the cartoon on the easel and bends down to examine it closely. The two of them, George and Mary, are now seated together on the divan. For a brief moment, there is silence, but then Mary begins to sing along with the phonograph record that has been playing throughout the entire scene. George glances at his watch, as if considering leaving, appearing somewhat uncomfortable. In response, she tries desperately to keep their conversation alive. Meanwhile, Mrs. Hatch, dressed in a bathrobe and with her hair set in curlers, leans over the banister as she calls down. George and Mary remain seated together on the divan, with George looking completely aghast. As George leaves the room, the telephone in the hall begins to ring. Mary enters the hall. As she picks up the phone, George re-enters from the front porch, stopping, hat in hand, to catch the first greetings. She passes the phone to George. Sam, seated at his desk with two of his friends nearby enjoying highballs, is on the other end. Upon hearing this, she hastily hangs up the extension phone she was using to eavesdrop. Mary then takes the telephone from George, holding it in such a way that George's cheek finds itself almost touching hers. George is acutely aware of her closeness. All the while, Mary attentively watches George, clearly interested. George is intensely conscious of her presence, so near to him. As Mary listens to the conversation, she turns to look at George, her lips nearly brushing against his. Finally, George’s self-control reaches its limit, and he can stand it no longer.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: He remains silent for a brief moment, seemingly lost in thought, before suddenly blurting out unexpected words that catch everyone off guard. By this time, a curious and intrigued small crowd has gathered, eager to witness the scene unfolding before them. Violet is absolutely furious, her anger causing her voice to rise to a loud and piercing volume, while George makes a concerted effort to calm her down. As George finally, in a state of frustration, stalks off, the assembled crowd erupts into laughter at the spectacle. George is then seen walking slowly and deliberately past the familiar Hatch home. He continues to walk a few yards beyond the house before turning around and beginning the journey back once more. Mary, observing from the window with great interest, watches George as he paces back and forth, with each step indicating his agitation. Yet, after only a few steps, he turns around once more and retraces his path, as if unable to make up his mind. George suddenly stops in his tracks, startled, and glances upward in surprise. But by that time, Mary has already vanished from the window, her excitement bubbling over. Mary, filled with anticipation about George's visit, is quickly running down the stairs. At the bottom of the stairs, she pauses momentarily to glance into a mirror and hurriedly tidies her hair. Filled with eagerness, she runs into the parlor and places a sketch on an easel. The drawing is a whimsical and imaginative caricature depicting George throwing a lasso around the moon. Then, with a sense of expectancy, she opens the front door and stands there, waiting for George to arrive. George struggles with the gate; after some effort, he finally manages to kick it open and begins to walk slowly up the path toward Mary. Now, Mary and George find themselves standing together in the entrance hall. They proceed through the doorway and make their way into the parlor. There, George notices the cartoon displayed on the easel and bends down to examine it closely with interest. The two of them, George and Mary, are now seated together on the divan. For a brief moment, there is silence, but then Mary begins to sing along with the phonograph record that has been playing throughout the entire scene. George glances at his watch, as though considering leaving, appearing somewhat uncomfortable and uncertain. In response, she tries desperately to keep their conversation alive, searching for topics to discuss. Meanwhile, Mrs. Hatch, dressed in a bathrobe and with her hair set in curlers, leans over the banister as she calls down, adding a touch of domesticity to the scene. George and Mary remain seated together on the divan, with George looking completely aghast and taken aback. As George leaves the room, the telephone in the hall begins to ring. Mary enters the hall. As she picks up the phone, George re-enters from the front porch, stopping, hat in hand, to catch the first greetings on the line. She passes the phone to George. Sam, seated at his desk with two of his friends nearby enjoying highballs, is on the other end of the line. Upon hearing this, she hastily hangs up the extension phone she was using to eavesdrop. Mary then takes the telephone from George, holding it in such a way that George's cheek finds itself almost touching hers, creating a sense of intimacy. George is acutely aware of her closeness and the effect it has on him. All the while, Mary attentively watches George, clearly interested in his presence and demeanor. George is intensely conscious of her nearness, so close to him. As Mary listens to the conversation, she turns to look at George, her lips nearly brushing against his in a tantalizing manner. Finally, George’s self-control reaches its limit, and he can stand it no longer, overwhelmed by the situation.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He stands silent momentarily, but then abruptly blurts out, drawing attention to himself unintentionally. By now, a modest crowd has gathered around, intrigued by the scene that’s unfolding. Violet, clearly furious, raises her voice in anger, while George makes attempts to calm her down, trying to hush her without much success. Feeling overwhelmed by the situation, George decides to leave abruptly, and as he walks away, the gathered crowd erupts into laughter, unable to contain their amusement. George, now alone, proceeds to walk slowly past the Hatch home, moving at a measured pace. He continues walking past the house for a few yards before stopping and deciding to turn back, retracing his steps. Unbeknownst to George, Mary has been observing him intently from her window, her eyes following his progress as he paces back and forth. After a few more tentative steps, George pivots once more and begins walking back in the direction he came. Suddenly, he halts, his attention drawn upward, his expression one of surprise as he notices something unexpected, but by then, Mary has already vanished from the window. Downstairs, Mary is moving rapidly, running down the stairs with an air of excitement. Reaching the bottom, she pauses briefly in front of a mirror to adjust her hair, ensuring she looks presentable for George's visit, clearly thrilled by the prospect of seeing him. Hurriedly, she enters the parlor and arranges a sketch on an easel, a whimsical caricature depicting George lassoing the moon, before she swings open the front door to await his arrival. Meanwhile, George struggles with the stubborn gate, eventually resorting to kicking it open in a bid to make it yield, and slowly proceeds up the path towards the waiting Mary. Once inside the entrance hall with Mary, they continue through the doorway into the parlor together. There, George's attention is immediately captivated by the cartoon, prompting him to bend down to examine it closely, taking in the details. Soon, George and Mary find themselves seated side by side on the divan, a silence settling between them momentarily. Breaking the silence, Mary starts singing along with the phonograph record that has been playing the whole time, her voice joining the music. George, feeling the weight of time, glances at his watch, signaling his intention to possibly leave, a gesture that betrays his discomfort. Sensing his unease, Mary makes an effort to sustain the conversation, eager to keep him engaged. At this moment, Mrs. Hatch appears upstairs, leaning over the banister in a bathrobe with her hair styled in curlers, calling out. Seated together on the divan, George is visibly shocked. As he exits the room, the telephone begins to ring in the hallway. Mary follows him out and picks up the receiver, only for George to re-enter from the front porch, having hesitated to hear the initial conversation. After listening briefly, she hands the phone to George. Meanwhile, on the other end of the line, Sam is seated at his desk with a drink in hand, accompanied by friends also holding highballs. Mary, having been listening on an extension phone, hurriedly hangs it up upon hearing the conversation. Taking the telephone from George, she positions it such that George's cheek is almost touching hers, a close proximity that makes him acutely aware of her presence. Mary regards George intently, her focus unwavering. As they listen, she turns slightly to face him, her lips nearing his, and the proximity and tension become too much for George to bear, compelling him to react.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
After a moment of silence, he suddenly speaks out, drawing the attention of a small crowd watching the scene. Violet, furious and loud, is calmed by George, who eventually walks off, prompting laughter from the crowd. As he walks slowly past the Hatch home, Mary observes him pacing back and forth from her window. Startled, George notices Mary has disappeared from view as she rushes downstairs, checks her appearance in the mirror, and excitedly prepares the parlor by placing a caricature of George on an easel before opening the front door to await him.

George struggles with the gate, eventually kicking it open before approaching Mary. Once inside, they move to the parlor where George examines the cartoon closely. Sitting together on the divan in silence, Mary joins a phonograph record in song, attempting to sustain the conversation as George, appearing uncomfortable, checks his watch as if to leave. Meanwhile, Mrs. Hatch calls down from the stairs, surprising George as he and Mary continue on the divan.

As George prepares to depart, the telephone rings in the hall. Mary answers it as George lingers by the door, intrigued by the first greetings. After taking the phone from Mary, their proximity causes George to feel very aware of her closeness. Mary watches him intently, and as their faces near, George reaches his limit and reacts to the situation.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description:
He is silent for a moment, then blurts out in a place known for its lively street scenes. By this time, a small crowd, drawn as always by any unusual activity in the bustling town square, has collected to watch the above scene. Violet, who is known for her fiery temper ever since her high school days, is furious and talking in a loud voice, and George is trying to quiet her as discreetly as he can. As George stalks off, the crowd, ever eager for an impromptu spectacle, breaks into laughter. 

George is walking slowly past the Hatch home, a quaint Victorian house that has stood for over a century. He walks past the house a few yards, turns, and starts back again, deep in thought. Mary, who has lived on this street her entire life, is looking out the window, watching George walk back and forth with an intent curiosity. But after a few steps, he turns around and starts back, pacing as though he’s rehearsing a speech. George stops, startled, and looks up at the sight of a familiar face; George looks surprised at this unexpected encounter. But Mary has disappeared from the window, eager to meet him. Mary is running down the stairs, her excitement palpable in the air. 

Mary looks in a mirror at the bottom of the stairs and fixes her hair, a habit she developed from watching old black-and-white romance films. She is plainly excited at George's visit as she remembers the last time they saw each other. She runs into the parlor and puts a sketch on an easel, showcasing her talent that once won her a local art contest. It is a caricature of George throwing a lasso around the moon, a playful nod to his dreamer’s personality. Then she opens the front door and stands there, filled with anticipation, waiting for George. 

George is struggling with the gate; he finally kicks it open, a relic from his childhood mischief, and starts slowly up the path toward Mary. Mary and George are in the entrance hall, which still bears the scent of the roses Mary’s mother loves to keep. They go through the doorway into the parlor, a room filled with the warmth of shared memories. George sees the cartoon on the easel and bends down for a close look at it, amused by her artistic touch. George and Mary are sitting on the divan, which has been in the family for generations. There is silence for a moment, then Mary joins in singing with the phonograph record, a vintage piece she inherited from her grandmother, which has been playing all through the above scene. 

He looks at his watch, a gift from his late grandfather, as though about to leave. He is uncomfortable, and she tries desperately to keep the conversation alive, remembering their past shared laughs. Mrs. Hatch, in a bathrobe and with her hair in curlers, is leaning over the banister, a common pose from her evening routine, as she calls: George and Mary are seated on the divan. George is aghast, his face reminiscent of the time he first encountered Mrs. Hatch’s formidable presence. As George leaves the room, the telephone in the hall, an old rotary model, starts ringing. 

Mary comes into the hall, her mind racing with possibilities. As Mary picks up the phone, George comes in from the front porch, still clutching his lucky hat. George has stopped, hat in hand, to hear the first greetings, curious about the caller. She hands the instrument to George, knowing it might be important. Sam, who attended college with George and Mary, is seated at his desk, while a couple of his friends, who are known for their weekend gatherings, are nearby with highballs in their hands. As she hears this, she hastily hangs up the extension phone on which she has been listening, a playful habit she picked up from childhood games of spy. 

Mary takes the telephone from George and holds it so that of necessity George's cheek is almost against hers, drawing him closer than ever. He is very conscious of her proximity, the scent of her lavender perfume filling the small space between them. Mary is watching George interestedly, curious about his reaction. George is very conscious of her, close to him, as memories of their past interactions flood back. As Mary listens, she turns to look at George, her lips almost on his lips, the moment charged with unspoken emotions. George can stand it no longer, overwhelmed by the shared history and the undeniable connection between them.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: George and Violet argue loudly in front of a gathered crowd, prompting George to leave in frustration. As he slowly paces outside the Hatch home, Mary watches him from her window, excited by his presence. Mary quickly prepares for his visit, setting up a sketch of George lassoing the moon. She eagerly waits for him at the door. George struggles with the gate but eventually makes his way to the parlor with Mary. They sit together, listening to music, and Mary sings along. Despite feeling uncomfortable, George stays. Mrs. Hatch interrupts from upstairs, which surprises George. As he prepares to leave, the phone rings, and Mary hands it to him, connecting him to Sam. She then listens in on an extension. Mary and George are drawn closer as they share the phone, leading to rising tension until George can no longer contain his feelings.

test_cases.name: Jumble Segments Order
test_cases.description: George looks surprised at this As George stalks off the crowd breaks into laughter But Mary has disappeared from the window Mrs Hatch in a bathrobe and with her hair in curlers is leaning over the banister as she calls He is very conscious of her proximity Mary and George are in the entrance hall George can stand it no longer He is uncomfortable and she tries desperately to keep the conversation alive George is walking slowly past the Hatch home She hands the instrument to George There is silence for a moment Mary is running down the stairs As George leaves the room the telephone in the hall starts ringing George and Mary are sitting on the divan Mary looks in a mirror at the bottom of the stairs and fixes her hair He looks at his watch as though about to leave Mary takes the telephone from George and holds it so that of necessity George's cheek is almost against hers George has stopped hat in hand to hear the first greetings She is plainly excited at George's visit then Mary joins in singing with the phonograph record which has been playing all through the above scene George sees the cartoon on the easel and bends down for a close look at it George is aghast Mary is watching George interestedly Mary comes into the hall They go through the doorway into the parlor Then she opens the front door and stands there waiting for George As Mary listens she turns to look at George her lips almost on his lips As she hears this she hastily hangs up the extension phone on which she has been listening As Mary picks up the phone George comes in from the front porch He is silent for a moment then blurts out Violet is furious and talking in a loud voice and George is trying to quiet her George and Mary are seated on the divan He walks past the house a few yards turns and starts back again Sam is seated at his desk while a couple of his friends are nearby with highballs in their hands Mary is looking out the window watching George walk back and forth George stops startled and looks up She runs into the parlor and puts a sketch on an easel It is a caricature of George throwing a lasso around the moon George is struggling with the gate he finally kicks it open and starts slowly up the path toward Mary By this time a small crowd has collected to watch the above scene But after a few steps he turns around and starts back George is very conscious of her close to him

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: There is silence for a moment then Mary joins in singing with the phonograph record which has been playing all through the above scene He looks at his watch as though about to leave He is uncomfortable and she tries desperately to keep the conversation alive Mrs Hatch in a bathrobe and with her hair in curlers is leaning over the banister as she calls George and Mary are seated on the divan George is aghast As George leaves the room the telephone in the hall starts ringing Mary comes into the hall As Mary picks up the phone George comes in from the front porch George has stopped hat in hand to hear the first greetings She hands the instrument to George Sam is seated at his desk while a couple of his friends are nearby with highballs in their hands As she hears this she hastily hangs up the extension phone on which she has been listening Mary takes the telephone from George and holds it so that of necessity George's cheek is almost against hers He is very conscious of her proximity Mary is watching George interestedly George is very conscious of her close to him As Mary listens she turns to look at George her lips almost on his lips George can stand it no longer He is silent for a moment then blurts out By this time a small crowd has collected to watch the above scene Violet is furious and talking in a loud voice and George is trying to quiet her As George stalks off the crowd breaks into laughter George is walking slowly past the Hatch home He walks past the house a few yards turns and starts back again Mary is looking out the window watching George walk back and forth But after a few steps he turns around and starts back George stops startled and looks up George looks surprised at this But Mary has disappeared from the window Mary is running down the stairs Mary looks in a mirror at the bottom of the stairs and fixes her hair She is plainly excited at George's visit She runs into the parlor and puts a sketch on an easel It is a caricature of George throwing a lasso around the moon Then she opens the front door and stands there waiting for George George is struggling with the gate he finally kicks it open and starts slowly up the path toward Mary Mary and George are in the entrance hall They go through the doorway into the parlor George sees the cartoon on the easel and bends down for a close look at it George and Mary are sitting on the divan
